posts.text: Xi Jinping met a group of “nongchaoer”, a Chinese term referring to those who “ride the tide” of great economic changes, just before the lunar holiday. We explain how they are different from magnates of the past https://www.economist.com/china/2026/02/24/how-to-get-rich-in-modern-china
posts.author: TheEconomist

posts.text:
Indian investors are rushing into gold at an unprecedented pace:

Gold ETF inflows in India are up to ~250 billion rupees, an all-time high.

As a result, inflows into gold funds have surpassed equity mutual fund inflows for the first time.

This comes as gold ETF inflows have risen more than +900% since July.

Over the same period, equity fund inflows have declined -170 billion rupees.

As the world's 2nd-largest gold consumer and one of its biggest importers, India's shift toward gold ETFs marks a fundamental change in how its investors are allocating their capital.

Indian retail investors are choosing gold over equities.
posts.author: KobeissiLetter

posts.text:
I would argue the opposite… Hydrograph is an Nanotech IP company that has been lost and unappreciated because it’s been marketing on the CSE amongst shitco miners.  

The audience is completely clueless to what Hydrograph $hg $hgraf is all about.   

Jaded investor group that doesn’t have a clue how to value it or if they should believe in it. So they have to wait for EPA approvals and other major milestones to see the forest through the trees. 

It’s moving to the Nasdaq and is now marketing to a world that is desperate for nanomaterials and graphene tech. Especially high tech applications and advanced biotech 

Very few mining guys got it… only the curious deep dive types.   Jay was willing to look. Guys like Doug Casey and Jim Rogers have been on the hunt for a viable graphene solution for ages.  They get it.
